lines.text: NEWS RELEASE FROM THE TOBACCO INSTITUTE FOR USE A DAY OR TWO
FOLLOWING RELEASE OF NEWS ABOUT HIRAYAMA'S STATISTICAL FINDING.
The following statement from The Tobacco Institute is
for immediate use:
A new report from thc American Cancer Society has
further contradicted a suggestion from a controversial and widely
publicized Japanese study that smokers expose their wives to
'significantly increased risks of lung cancer.
This follows the disclosure earlier this weck by thrce
independent statisticians of a fundamental miscalculation in
the Japanese study. That report came from Nathan Mantel of the
George Washington University Biostatistics Center, Dr. Alvan R.
Feinstein of Yale University and Dr. Chris P. Tsokos of the
University of South Florida.
" In a study of lung cancer trends in a population far
larger than the Japanesc group, the chief statistician for the
Cancer Society, Lawrence Garfinkel, has found no significant
elevation of lung cancer mortality among nonsmoking women married
to smokers compared with those married to nonsmokers.
Garfinkel's work was published today
in the Journal of
the National Cancer Institutle. It includes approximately 176,000
married, nonsmoking women in America who have been studied for
more than 20 years.

full_text:
NEWS RELEASE FROM THE TOBACCO INSTITUTE FOR USE A DAY OR TWO
FOLLOWING RELEASE OF NEWS ABOUT HIRAYAMA'S STATISTICAL FINDING.
The following statement from The Tobacco Institute is
for immediate use:
 A new report from thc American Cancer Society has
further contradicted a suggestion from a controversial and widely
publicized Japanese study that smokers expose their wives to
'significantly increased risks of lung cancer.
This follows the disclosure earlier this weck by thrce
independent statisticians of a fundamental miscalculation in
the Japanese study. That report came from Nathan Mantel of the
George Washington University Biostatistics Center, Dr. Alvan R.
Feinstein of Yale University and Dr. Chris P. Tsokos of the
University of South Florida.
" In a study of lung cancer trends in a population far
larger than the Japanesc group, the chief statistician for the
Cancer Society, Lawrence Garfinkel, has found no significant
elevation of lung cancer mortality among nonsmoking women married
to smokers compared with those married to nonsmokers.
Garfinkel's work was published today
in the Journal of
the National Cancer Institutle. It includes approximately 176,000
married, nonsmoking women in America who have been studied for
more than 20 years.
03020290
